questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a 1-week history of fever, irritability, decreased appetite, and lethargy. Examination reveals high temperature, moderate hepatomegaly, and purpura/petechiae on the trunk and extremities. CBC shows thrombocytopenia and leukopenia. ELISA detects antibodies for antigen PP65. What is the cause of the condition?
questions.explanation:
CMV infection

Modes of transmission
  • Oral route, respiratory & body secretions (most common)
  • Vertical transmission
  • Sexual transmission
  • Organ transplantation
  • Blood transfusion

Host cells
  • Salivary gland
  • Kidney

Clinical features

Congenital infection
  • Most common intrauterine infection with congenital defects.
  • Common presentation:
    • Petechiae
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Jaundice
  • Less common presentation:
    • Microcephaly
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Intrauterine growth retardation
    • Prematurity
  • Other defects: Sensorineural hearing loss.

Perinatal infection
  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Occasionally, premature infants present with interstitial pneumonitis.

Immunocompromised
  • Seen in AIDS, HIV, organ transplant patients and cancer patients undergoing chemo
  • Presentations in AIDS and HIV
    • CMV chorioretinitis
    • Progressive dementia,
    • Cranial nerve defects,
  • Presentations in Organ transplant
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia
    • Febrile leukopenia
    • Obliterative bronchiolitis
    • Graft atherosclerosis
    • Rejection of renal allografts.

Immunocompetent
  • Usually, it occurs following a blood transfusion.
  • It presents similar to infectious mononucleosis, but heterophile antibody tests would be negative.

Investigations

Peripheral smear

Owl’s eye appearance of inclusion bodies

Virus isolation

It is done by

  • Human fibroblast cell line culture
  • Shell vial culture

Antigen detected

PP65

Antibody detection

It is done by ELISA, and the antibodies detected are

  • CMV IgM antibodies
  • CMV IgG antibodies
  • Against PP150 and PP65,
  • Against the PP52

PCR
  • Used in detecting CMV DNA
  • Quantitative nucleic acid testing (QNAT) by PCR is the most sensitive and specific testing.

Treatment
  • Ganciclovir (Drug of choice)
  • Foscarnet (in Ganciclovir resistance)
  • CMV immunoglobulins and Ganciclovir are given to bone marrow transplant patients.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with fatigue, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes. He reports recent unprotected sexual encounters and has a history of intravenous drug use. During further investigation of his blood sample, a specific particle associated with this viral infection is identified under the electron microscope. Which of the following structures, when transmitted, is capable of leading to infection in another person?
questions.explanation:
Particle Type

Size (nm)

Infectious

Dane Particles (Option D)

42

Yes

Tubular Particles (Option B)

22

No

No

Surface proteins (Medium HBsAg)

Filamentous Particles (Option C)

22

No

No

questions.text: Based on the properties of viruses, which of the following sentences is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: A virus can either possess DNA or RNA, but never both.

options.label: B
options.text: All animal viruses are spherical in shape.

options.label: C
options.text: Viruses are obligate intracellular and can only replicate inside a host cell.

options.label: D
options.text: All viruses have a protein coat that encases their genetic material.

questions.correct_answer: B. All animal viruses are spherical in shape.
questions.explanation:
General properties of viruses

Characteristics

  • They do not have a cellular organisation.
  • Obligate intracellular parasites - cannot replicate outside a host. (Option C)
  • Lack enzymes necessary for protein and nucleic acid synthesis.
  • Multiply via a complex process.
  • They cannot be cultured in cell-free culture media but can grow in embryonated eggs or tissue culture.
  • They can pass through filters.

Morphology

  • All viruses have a protein coat that encases their genetic material.
  • Either possess DNA or RNA but never both. (Option A)
  • Nucleic acid is enclosed by a protein capsid, which may or may not be enclosed by a lipid envelope. (Option D)

Shape
  • Most are spherical. (Option B)
  • Some are irregular and pleomorphic
  • Different shapes of animal viruses are
    • Rabies virus - bullet-shaped
    • Ebola virus - filamentous
    • Pox virus - brick shaped
    • Tobacco mosaic virus - rod-shaped

Size

Ranges from 300 nm - Poxvirus to 20 nm - Parvovirus

questions.text: Pair the viruses with their corresponding shapes 1. Rabies virus A. 2. Ebola virus B. 3. Pox virus C. 4. Tobacco-mosaic virus D.

questions.text: A virology lab receives samples from a patient with a suspected viral infection presenting with fever, cough, and body aches. Testing confirms the presence of an RNA virus. Which of the following is an example of an RNA virus?
questions.explanation:
DNA virus

RNA virus

Herpesviridae:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1, HSV-2)
  • Varicella-zoster virus
  • Epstein-Barr virus (Option A)
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • HHV-6,7,8

Hepadnaviridae:

  • Hepatitis B virus

Parvoviridae:

  • Parvovirus B19

Papovaviridae:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  • JC virus (Option B)
  • BK virus

Poxviridae:

  • Variola virus (smallpox)
  • Molluscum contagiosum virus

Adenoviridae:

  • Human adenovirus (Option C)

Bacteriophage

Picornaviridae:

  • Poliovirus
  • Coxsackievirus
  • Rhinovirus
  • Hepatitis A virus
  • Enterovirus

Caliciviridae:

  • Hepatitis E virus

Togaviridae:

  • Rubella virus
  • Eastern equine encephalitis virus
  • Western equine encephalitis virus

Flaviviridae:

  • Yellow fever virus
  • Dengue virus
  • Hepatitis C virus
  • West Nile virus

Coronaviridae:

  • SARS-CoV
  • MERS-CoV
  • SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19)

Rhabdoviridae:

  • Rabies virus

Filoviridae:

  • Ebola virus

Paramyxoviridae:

  • Measles virus
  • Mumps virus
  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)
  • Nipah virus
  • Parainfluenza virus

Orthomyxoviridae:

  • Influenza viruses (A, B, C, D)

Bunyaviridae

Arenaviridae

Reoviridae:

  • Rotavirus
  • Reovirus
  • Colorado tick fever virus

Retroviridae:

  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  • Human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV)

questions.text: A patient’s cell culture exhibits distinct cytopathic effects characterised by the formation of syncytia (multinucleated giant cells). Based on these observations, which virus is most likely responsible for the infection?

A 45-year-old patient presents with neurological symptoms, and a brain biopsy is performed, revealing the presence of inclusion bodies as shown in the image. What are these inclusion bodies commonly referred to as?

(IFN-α)

(IFN-γ)

Structure

Glycoprotein

Source

Leukocytes

Fibroblasts and epithelial cells

Th1 (T-helper type 1) lymphocytes

Function

  • Antiviral properties
  • Used for multiple sclerosis.
  • Immunomodulatory and anti-proliferative (granuloma formation).
  • Treatment of chronic granulomatous disease.

Chromosome (interferon)

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with fever, malaise, and a bright red "slapped cheek" rash on his face, which later spreads to his trunk and extremities. Blood tests reveal mild anaemia. The clinical diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is made. What are the characteristics of the virus responsible for this condition?

A 30-year-old female is diagnosed with cervical dysplasia, and HPV testing reveals a high-risk strain. A histopathological examination of her cervical biopsy shows the following findings. Which viral protein is associated with the formation of these findings?
questions.explanation:
HPV is a DNA virus belonging to the Papillomaviridae family.

Tropism: Selectively infects epithelial cells of skin and mucous membranes.

Morphology

  • Non-enveloped virus, 50–55 nm in size.
  • Icosahedral capsid containing circular double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

Viral Genome

Early (E) Region: Includes E1-E7 genes coding for nonstructural proteins.

  • E1 and E2 Proteins: Regulate viral DNA replication. (Option A)
  • E4 Protein: Disrupts cytokeratins to facilitate the release of the virus.
  • E5 Protein: contributes to the formation of perinuclear vacuoles, leading to cytoplasmic “halos.” (Option D)
  • E6 Protein: Promotes degradation of the p53 tumor-suppressor protein. (Option B)
  • E7 Protein: inhibits retinoblastoma protein, contributing to oncogenesis. (Option C)

Late (L) Region: L1 and L2 genes code for structural capsid proteins.

  • Types: Over 100 HPV types, classified by DNA sequences in the L1 region.
  • L1 capsid protein is used for making vaccines.

HPV Mechanism of Oncogenesis
 
  • E6 Protein:
    • Promotes degradation of p53, blocking apoptosis and inhibiting p53-driven activation of tumor suppressor gene p21.
  • E7 Protein:
    • Inhibits the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor gene through direct RB inhibition and by interfering with p53 and p21 functions.
  • HPV infection alone is insufficient for malignancy; factors such as co-transfection with v-fos DNA, genetic mutations (e.g., mutated RAS gene), & environmental influences (e.g., smoking, microbial co-infections, dietary deficiencies, hormonal changes) enhance cancer risk.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the physician as he developed lesions on the body, as below. Which of the following statements would be false about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: These are caused by molluscum contagiosum virus

options.label: B
options.text: The lesions can be seen all over the body

options.label: C
options.text: This is transmitted through direct and indirect contact

questions.correct_answer: B. The lesions can be seen all over the body
questions.explanation:
Molluscum contagiosum

Molluscum contagiosum virus is an obligate human poxvirus known for producing characteristic skin lesions. (Option A)






 

Clinical manifestations







 

Lesions:

  • Dome-shaped, pink, pearly wart-like lesions (2–5 mm in size) with a dimple at the center.
  • Lesions can appear singly or in clusters, located anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles.
  • Lesions are umbilicated.
  • Genital lesions are commonly observed in adults.
  • Lesions typically resolve on their own within 3–4 months. (Option D)

 
 

Transmission

  • Primarily affects children, transmitted through direct and indirect contact (e.g., barbers, shared towels, swimming pools). (Option C)
  • Rare instances of sexual transmission have been reported in young adults.

Laboratory diagnosis


 

Molluscum bodies:

  • Characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions were observed in skin scrapings stained with histopathological stains.
 

Confirmation methods:

  • Electron microscopy
  • PCR
 

Cultivation:

  • The virus cannot be propagated in tissue culture, embryonated eggs, or animals.

Treatment

Surgical removal of the lesions by ablation (by cryotherapy or laser therapy) is the mainstay of treatment.

Cidofovir has been shown to have some efficacy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child is brought by her mother with complaints of redness of the eyes with watery discharge. She also complains of a sore throat and fever and gives a history of being in a swimming pool at school. Which serotype of the virus causing this condition is responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Adenovirus

  • Adenoviruses are non-enveloped DNA viruses characterized by icosahedral symmetry.
  • They feature fiber proteins extending from each vertex, creating a distinctive appearance reminiscent of a space vehicle.

Morphology

  • Adenoviruses range from 70 to 75 nm in diameter.
  • It is composed of 252 capsomers forming an icosahedron.
  • Capsomer Types: Hexons and Pentons.
  • Each penton includes:
    • A penton base anchored in the capsid.
    • A fiber projection consisting of a rod-like portion with a knob at the end.

Clinical manifestations

While many serotypes can cause disease, types 1–7 are the most prevalent.





 

Respiratory infections

Upper respiratory tract infections:

  • Common in children
  • Primarily caused by serotypes 1, 2, and 5. (Option A)
  • In adolescents, serotypes 3, 4, and 7 are responsible for mild infections.

Pneumonia:

  • Types 3, 7, and 21 account for 10-20% of childhood pneumonia cases. (Option D)
  • Serotype 14 is linked to severe pneumonia in healthy young adults.

Acute respiratory disease:

  • Occur as outbreaks, especially in military recruits.
  • Associated with types 4, 7, and occasionally type 3.

Transplant recipients:

  • Serotypes 34 and 35 are frequently isolated from these patients.

Ocular Infections

Pharyngoconjunctival fever:

  • Outbreaks typically occur in children's summer camps.
  • Often referred to as swimming pool conjunctivitis.
  • Associated with serotypes 3, 7, and 14.

Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis:

  • Known as shipyard eye.
  • It is highly contagious in adults.
  • Caused by types 8, 19, and 37. (Option B)

Gastrointestinal Infections

Infantile gastroenteritis:

  • Serotypes 40 and 41 are responsible for 5-15% of viral gastroenteritis cases in young children.

Urinary Tract Infections

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis:

  • Primarily affects children, especially boys.
  • Caused by serotypes 11 and 21.

Swimming pool-associated diseases

Causative agents

Swimming pool granuloma

Mycobacterium marinum (atypical mycobacterium)

Swimmer’s itch

Trematode parasites like cercaria

Swimmer’s ear

Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Staphylococcus aureus

Swimming pool conjunctivitis

Chemical irritants like chlorine

Human adenovirus

Chlamydia trachomatis

Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: A 25-year-old man visits urgent care with painful lip sores and a fever, which began after a recent cold and increased work stress. Examination reveals vesicular lesions around his lips (as shown below) and swollen lymph nodes in his neck, suggesting infection by an enveloped double-stranded DNA virus. Which feature is associated with this organism?
questions.correct_answer: C. Latency occurs in trigeminal ganglion
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV 1)

Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV 2)

Transmission

Mucosal membrane or abraded skin

Sexual or vertical (mother to baby) (Option A)

Site of latency

Trigeminal ganglia (Option C)

Sacral ganglia

Age group

Children

Adults (Option D)

Clinical features

  • Skin lesions above the waist (oral lesions like gingivostomatitis and labialis)
  • Encephalitis
  • Meningitis
  • Skin lesions below the waist (mainly genital lesions) - Painful
  • Neonatal herpes (vertical transmission) (Option B)

Growth on chick embryo fibroblasts

Poor growth

Good growth

(larger pox resembling variola)

Neurovirulence

Less

More

Drug resistance

Less

More

Temperature sensitivity

Less

More

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 20 weeks gestation reports a mild rash, fever, and flu-like symptoms after exposure to a child with a rash. Ultrasound shows cicatricial lesions, limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, and intrauterine growth restriction. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old child presents with fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and spots on the buccal mucosa as shown below after a recent family trip. The mother reports no vaccinations. Which statement best describes the incubation period and transmission mode of the suspected illness?

options.label: C
options.text: Incubation period: 3-5 days; contaminated surfaces only

options.label: D
options.text: Incubation period: 7-8 days; direct skin contact

questions.correct_answer: B. Incubation period: 10-14 days; respiratory droplets
